content: The "Family Act of 2011" may be cited as the official title of this Act. The "Family Act of 2011" may be cited as the official title of this Act. Congress recognizes infertility as a disease and a public health priority, with limited insurance coverage for treatments like in vitro fertilization. Only 8 states have laws requiring comprehensive infertility coverage, leading to significant out-of-pocket expenses for affected individuals. The "Family Act of 2011" recognizes infertility as a disease and a public health priority, with limited insurance coverage for treatments like in vitro fertilization. A new section, SEC. 23A, provides a credit for certain infertility treatments in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Family Act of 2011" introduces a credit for infertility treatment expenses in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Eligible individuals can receive a credit of 50% of qualified expenses, up to a limit of $13,360 per year. The credit is reduced based on income exceeding $150,000. Infertility is defined as the inability to conceive or carry a pregnancy to live birth, excluding infertility resulting from procedures designed for sterilization. Eligible individuals must be diagnosed with infertility by a licensed physician. Married taxpayers must file joint returns for this credit. Adjustments for inflation apply.
